item.title: In His First Speech, King Charles III Pledges Service to Britain
item.description: On a day of mourning in Britain after the death of Queen Elizabeth, Charles’s ascent to the throne was a symbol of the continuity of the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III outside Buckingham Palace on Friday.

item.title: Camilla Becomes Queen Consort. Here’s What the Title Means.
item.description: Upon Queen Elizabeth’s death, there was no question that as her son became King Charles III, Camilla would become queen consort. Elizabeth put the issue of Camilla’s role to rest earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Charles, left, chats with Camilla Parker Bowles at a polo match, circa 1972.

item.title: King Charles to Replace Queen Elizabeth on Bank Notes and Coins
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II faced right on British coins. Her son and successor might face the other way.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Since the 17th century, British monarchs have faced the opposite direction of their predecessors on coins.

item.title: Ukraine Attacks Russia in the Kharkiv Region, Swiftly Making Gains
item.description: Sweeping south from positions in the Kharkiv region in Ukraine’s northeast, Ukrainian forces have made their largest gains since routing Russia from Kyiv in April.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marco Hernandez
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters in Kharkiv on Friday. President Volodymyr Zelensky said his military had captured large chunks of occupied territory in the north.

item.title: The American Guided Rockets Helping Ukraine Destroy Russian Forces
item.description: The Guided Multiple Launch Rocket System can hit targets 50 miles away with 200 pounds of explosives.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: An M142 High Mobility Artillery Rocket System launching a salvo during exercises last year in Morocco.

item.title: Justice Dept. and Trump Legal Team Clash Over Special Master Candidates
item.description: The two sides had sharply diverging views of who could serve as a special master and what that person would do.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Agents seized more than 11,000 government documents, including about 100 marked as classified, from Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s residence in Palm Beach, Fla.

item.title: Stephen Miller and Brian Jack Among Those Subpoenaed in Jan. 6 Case
item.description: Stephen Miller, a senior policy adviser, and Brian Jack, who served as White House political director, are among those who received requests for information this week from a federal grand jury.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, left, with Hogan Gidley, the former White House deputy press secretary.

item.title: Carlos Alcaraz Outlasts Frances Tiafoe to Reach the US Open Final
item.description: The 19-year-old from Spain ended the talented American’s deep run in New York in five sets and will play Casper Ruud of Norway for the men’s singles title.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz is on to the men’s singles final of the U.S. Open.

item.title: Navy Orders High-Level Outside Investigation of SEAL Course
item.description: The punishing selection course for the Navy’s most elite force has come under new scrutiny after a sailor’s death exposed illicit drug use and other problems.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Yeshiva University Can Bar L.G.B.T. Club for Now, Sotomayor Rules
item.description: Sonia Sotomayor’s ruling will be in place pending a decision by the Supreme Court to take up the case.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Yeshiva requires male students to spend between one and six hours a day studying the Torah.

item.title: In New Hampshire, a MAGA Rivalry Is Splitting House Republicans
item.description: Two young conservatives are battling for the mantle of Trumpism in a congressional primary in a competitive district in New Hampshire that could help decide the House majority.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Karoline Leavitt, a Republican candidate in a congressional primary in New Hampshire, is backed by a host of hard-right Republicans, including Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

item.title: First Kansas, Next Michigan and Beyond as Abortion Ballot Measures Spread
item.description: Democrats are hoping ballot measures on abortion rights will drive up voter turnout. They’re looking to Michigan as a test run.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman and Nick Corasaniti
item.media:description: An abortion-rights rally earlier this summer in Lansing, Mich. Democrats in Michigan say a referendum on abortion will supercharge activism among many voters.

item.title: Galileo Forgery’s Trail Leads to Web of Mistresses and Manuscripts
item.description: The unmasking of a fake Galileo manuscript this summer brought renewed attention to a colorful, prolific early-20th-century forger named Tobia Nicotra.
item.dc:creator: Michael Blanding
item.media:description: The conviction of Tobia Nicotra, a notorious forger, was covered in The American Weekly in 1935.

item.title: A Filmmaker Explores David Bowie’s Life and Gets Clarity on His Own
item.description: With the epic “Moonage Daydream,” Brett Morgen contended with a chameleonic star whose approach to living helped him refocus after a heart attack.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: The Royal Grief You Will Not See
item.description: To mourn in public is to feel judged but supported, too.
item.dc:creator: Patti Davis
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Britain’s King Charles III and Queen Camilla at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Tina Brown: Queen Elizabeth II Loved Her Job
item.description: Without the queen, how will anyone know how to be British anymore?
item.dc:creator: Tina Brown
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
The Palace Papers: Inside the House of Windsor -- the Truth and the Turmoil (Book)

item.title: A Great Podcast, a Worthy Memoir and a Curdled Take on Clarence Thomas
item.description: A fall syllabus.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.category: Brooklyn College, City University of New York

item.title: What My Family and I Saw When We Were Trapped in China’s Heat Wave
item.description: On a trip through the epicenter, ravaged landscapes, paralyzed cities and populations pushed to extremes.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Bossons
item.media:description: A dry riverbed last month along the Jialing River, a major tributary of the Yangtze River, in Chongqing, China.

item.title: The Treasure America Scavenges From the Poor
item.description: The world’s blood banks are filled with “donations” collected in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Veselka

item.title: Biden Is Telling You That Trump Is a Threat, and the Proof Is Everywhere
item.description: Trump is the chosen candidate of reactionary billionaires and fanatical opponents of racial and gender equality for a reason.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:description: Speaking truth to Trump.

item.title: What This War Correspondent Wants You to Know About America and Fear
item.description: Luke Mogelson watches the country go berserk in “The Storm Is Here.”
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: The Storm Is Here: An American Crucible (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: How to Address the Child Therapist Shortage
item.description: Ways to make the work more sustainable for new and experienced therapists.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bonanno

item.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
item.description: Our TV critic recommends a darling cooking show, a juicy historical drama and an evocative orchestra performance.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Lyons
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:description: A scene from “The Tiny Chef Show.”

item.title: Did You Recently Buy an Electric Vehicle? We Want to Hear About It.
item.description: Sales of electric cars are surging as more people become interested in the technology and grow concerned about climate change.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:description: An electric vehicle charging in Los Angeles in August.

item.title: The Run-Up: The Stakes of the 2022 Midterm Elections
item.description: This November, Americans will head to the polls for the first major political test since Jan. 6.
item.media:credit: Photo illustration: Pablo Delcan; Photo: Samuel Corum for The New York Times

item.title: Why Can’t I Stand the Sound of Chewing? Misophonia, Explained
item.description: Misophonia, a little-known syndrome, is characterized by strong negative emotional reactions to certain sounds or visual cues.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Hochul Declares Polio State of Emergency for New York
item.description: The virus has now been detected in a Nassau County wastewater sample, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: State and local officials have been urging people to get immunized against polio since the virus was detected in wastewater earlier this summer.

item.title: Oberlin Says It Will Pay $36.59 Million to a Local Bakery
item.description: Gibson’s Bakery said the liberal arts college had falsely accused it of racism after a Black student was caught shoplifting.
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis
item.media:description: Gibson's Bakery, which is across the street from Oberlin College in Ohio.

item.title: Marc Lewitinn, Covid Patient, Dies at 76 After 850 Days on a Ventilator
item.description: While no definitive statistics exist, doctors say Mr. Lewitinn, a retired Manhattan store owner, was likely the longest-surviving intubated Covid patient.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Can Exercise Strengthen Your Immunity?
item.description: Recent research suggests that people who work out have stronger resistance to infectious diseases — including Covid — but experts say the findings need to be tested further.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times

item.title: A Do-Anywhere Full-Body Workout
item.description: It can be done in barely 30 minutes in a hotel room, garage or even an airport lounge. All you need is a jump rope.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds

item.title: How to Exercise Mindfully
item.description: Bringing meditation into your movement can enrich your workout and help you feel clearheaded afterward.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Marder
item.media:credit: Sasha Arutyunova for The New York Times

item.title: How to Start Liking Running
item.description: It’s good for your mental and physical health, and doesn’t require any equipment. So why does it seem so hard to get started?
item.dc:creator: Farah Miller

item.title: Can Moving the Body Heal the Mind?
item.description: In her new book, Jennifer Heisz blends personal experience and the latest science about how exercise can improve your mental well-being.
item.dc:creator: Gretchen Reynolds

item.title: U.S. Men’s Basketball on 1972 Munich Olympics: ‘We Deserve Gold Medals’
item.description: Fifty years after a painful, and controversial, loss to the Soviet Union in the 1972 Olympics, some American men’s basketball players still hope to be declared the rightful winners.
item.dc:creator: Scott Cacciola
item.media:description: The United States’ men’s basketball players were dejected when the Soviet Union was declared the winner of the gold medal game at the 1972 Olympics after receiving a do-over on a final play.
